sourcesContent:
import "./css/Duxford.css" import L4 from "./img/DSC_6158.jpg" function Duxford() { return (

Imperial War Museum Duxford

The Duxford Imperial War Museum is the largest military aircraft museum in Europe and hosts a number of major air shows each year. The museum's collection includes everything from World War I military aircraft to Concorde supersonic civilian aircraft, and includes the P-51 Mustang fighter and the huge B-52 bomber. In the museum's Land Warfare Hall, there is a collection of World War II vehicles, as well as a naval collection that includes British naval aircraft and the X-shaped mini-submarine. The museum is very large and other exhibits include the "British War Exhibit", "Forgotten Wars Exhibit", and "History of the Burma Campaign of World War II".

The museum's site was originally the historic Duxford Airfield, which played an important role in the First and Second World Wars. It was built as an RAF base during World War I. During World War II as a base for the Battle of Britain and later in the war was given to the United States Army Air Forces (USAAF) as its 357th base, becoming a base for air attacks on enemy aircraft Germany. After the war, it was returned to the RAF in December 1945. In 1969 the museum acquired the rights to use part of the airfield and in 1976 the whole airfield was handed over to the museum and opened to the public. As a historic site, many of the buildings of historical significance at Duxford Airfield have been retained as part of the collection or used as exhibition halls. Translated with www.DeepL.com/Translator (free version)

); } export default Duxford;
